title: ITV blast BBC for poaching talent including Holly Willoughby and Bradley Walsh
text:

ITV bosses have been left fuming over a raid on their big-name talent by BBC rivals.

Their anger comes after Holly Willoughby and Bradley Walsh – two of ITV's premier presenters – were signed up last month to front a BBC Christmas special, described as a “brand new family entertainment show”.

This follows a failed attempt to poach Good Morning Britain's Piers Morgan for a revived version of The Weakest Link and comes after Take Me Out's Paddy McGuinness was successfully snapped up for Top Gear.

Other stars to be “poached” include former Corrie favourite Catherine Tyldesley, who recently starred in new comedy Scarborough and Britain's Got Talent judge Alesha Dixon, who was hired as host of The Greatest Dancer alongside Dancing on Ice's Ashley Banjo.

(Image: WireImage)

(Image: ITV)

ITV chiefs believe their stars are being targeted because of the BBC's lack of homegrown talent with broad, down-to-earth appeal, particularly with younger viewers and northern audiences.

“Most of their TV stars are southern and perhaps a bit posh – a bit Radio 4,” one senior source said. “They are obsessed with youth and ITV does much better than them on 16-34 year old viewers. Plus they have an issue in the north where their viewing is bad and they worry about a licence fee rebellion.”

The insider added: “It would be nice if they could find some of their own stars and not just come poaching for ours.”

(Image: BBC Studios/Lee Brimble)

(Image: BBC Studios/Lee Brimble)

This Morning's Willoughby and The Chase's Walsh will front a festive special for the BBC in December called Take Off with Bradley and Holly.

The hour-long special will see the pair, best known as hosts of This Morning and The Chase, joining forces for a studio show in which audience members get the chance to win a trip to Lapland.

Made by Holly's producer husband Dan Baldwin, it promises to be “jam packed with incredible surprises, a gaggle of games and much more leading up to a spectacular end of show finale”.

(Image: PA)

(Image: ITV)

But the BBC are said to have paid “over the odds” with a six-figure sum to lure the pair over, which didn't make financial sense. “Holly and Bradley are firmly associated with ITV in the eyes of the viewers - and long may they stay that way,” the source said.

“It's cost the BBC a fortune in fees to poach them and the production costs on the show itself are around £1million. Is this licence fee value? Surely not.”

Holly, 36, paid herself £1.4 million last year, which included her £600,000 fees for This Morning. The rest of the money was earned through her work as presenter of ITV2's Celebrity Juice, as host of Dancing on Ice and as a brand ambassador for Marks and Spencer.

(Image: ITV)

Bradley's earnings were £4.6million in 2018, thanks to hundreds of episodes of his hit ITV quiz The Chase. All his presenting work has been with ITV although he is currently filming the second series of Doctor Who for the BBC, in which he plays one of the Time Lord's regular sidekicks.

Morgan was approached as a potential new host for a revival of The Weakest Link, which is not now going ahead. One insider revealed: “They couldn't agree on the money.”

Last night the BBC declined to comment.
description: EXCLUSIVE: ITV chiefs think their stars are being targeted by BBC bosses for their own shows after a recent signing
